Goal.Desc: Has received alcohol/substance use disorder self-management overview

Problem.Desc: Needs alcohol/substance use disorder self-management overview

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Understanding Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder- Understanding Family/Social Impact of Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder- Understanding Relapse Prevention for Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder- Understanding Treatment Options for Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What can you tell me about what a substance use disorder is?
NOTE: Praise member for correct responses
Substance use disorder is a term for addiction to alcohol or drugs, including prescription medicines not prescribed for you. These are serious conditions that:
  • Millions of people deal with every day
  • Affect rich, poor, all races, religions, and ages
  • May be inherited or "run in families"
  • Worsen over time
  • Harm the person with the substance use disorder, the family, and all other social contacts
  • Can cause the substance use disorder to take dangerous risks such as unprotected sex (can lead to HIV infection) or driving under the influence
  • Are medical conditions that can be treated
 
People withsubstance use disorders:
  • May be in denial about their problem, thinking they only drink a "normal" amount of alcohol, or that "everyone" takes drugs
  • May have cravings or a strong urge to drink or use drugs
  • May not be able to control their drinking or drug use once they start
  • May need to drink or use more to get "high"
  • Often struggle with depression, anxiety, or other mental health conditions that also need treatment
  • May develop financial, family, and legal problems because of alcohol or drug use
  • May have feelings of withdrawal such as nausea, sweating, shakiness or anxiety after stopping drinking or drug use
  • May develop other health conditions, such as diabetes or liver disease, that are caused by the substance they are addicted to
  • Need to recognize they have a disease
  • Need to ask for help; this is the first step toward recovery
  • Need to stop their behavior (drinking or drug using) with the help of their healthcare provider, a therapist, medicine, a support program, and their family or significant other(s)
 
Q: What questions do you have about this?
NOTE: Answer questions. If member talks about problems or difficulties with their condition, describe how you and member can identify problems and plan next steps.

EducationComponent.Title: Understanding Family/Social Impact of Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
People who have a substance use disorder may have a hard time keeping good relationships with people who matter to them. They may experience family, social, or legal problems such as divorce, domestic abuse, or other problems with friends and co-workers.
 
For families: Intervention
Getting a loved one to agree to accept help, and finding help for all family members, are the first steps toward healing. If a person with a substance use disorder is unwilling or slow to seek help, confronting them may help. This is when family members, friends, and co-workers come together out of concern and love for the person. They tell the person about how drinking or drug use negatively affects their relationship with him. They also talk about other possible effects, such as family break-ups, loss of friendship, and the cost of legal problems. This is called an "intervention". When this is done with the help of a trained counselor, the family and friends are usually able to convince their loved one (in a firm and loving manner) to enter treatment.
 
For children:
Children in families where there is alcohol or drug use need someone to guide and support them. It is important for the family to talk honestly about what is happening and help children talk about their feelings. Children need to be reassured that they will be safe and cared for.
 
Q: What are your thoughts or experiences with this problem?
NOTE: Listen with empathy
There are some things that you can do to help keep healthy relationships with those who matter to you.
Q: Would you like to hear about some things to do to help keep healthy relationships with those who matter to you?
NOTE: With permission 
  • Share what is going on with you. Tell people you trust that you have a substance use disorder.
    • Your healthcare provider can also be involved in discussing your condition with a person you trust, such as a loved one, friend, or clergy person. They will ask you to give written permission to share any information
  • Help educate others about substance use disorders
    • When others you care about understand your condition, they will be more likely, and better able, to help you
    • Your family or friends may even see signs and symptoms of you getting worse or better before you do!
  • Many people get better and recover from substance use disorders
    • Let your family and friends know that for most people recovery is expected
    • Looking forward to a common goal encourages everyone
  • Involve family and friends in the pleasant activities and outings you plan as part of your therapy
  • Seek family and/or marriage counseling if needed
  • Join a 12 step program or another substance abuse treatment group
  • Encourage your children 11 years and up to join a group such as Alateen
 
Q: What questions do you have about this?
NOTE: Answer questions or refer member to provider for answers

EducationComponent.Title: Understanding Relapse Prevention for Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Even though your recovery plan may be working now, it is important to keep doing things that help you stay on track to a full recovery. Many people who are in treatment relapse more than once before they completely quit drinking or using drugs. If this happens to you, don`t feel like you are a failure. Instead, keep working toward your goal. Make a plan to prevent another relapse.
 
Early warning signs of relapse may include:
  • Out of control cravings that make you want to drink or take drugs
  • Spending more time in places with people who drink or take drugs
  • Feelings of overconfidence or impatience with your treatment plan
  • Thinking "I can control my drug use if I only do it with my friends" or "This treatment isn`t working. I can`t stay on track."
  • Increased anxiety, nervousness
  • Withdrawal from others
     
Here are some helpful suggestions to prevent relapse:
  • Continue to take your medicine (if it is prescribed for you) for as long as your healthcare provider tells you to, even if you feel better. Do not change or stop taking the medicine without talking to your provider first
  • Avoid your personal "triggers" by not going places where alcohol or drugs are available. Find new friends that don`t drink or use. Develop new healthy activities or hobbies. Talk to your counselor about new ways to cope with the stress of recovering
  • Remind yourself of your reasons for quitting. It might be helpful to write them down and carry them with you to help in difficult situations
  • Know your "no". You are certain to be in a situation at some point where alcohol or drugs are available. Be ready with your "No thanks". The faster you can say "no" to these offers, the less likely you are to give in to them
  • Get support from others. Consider joining a support group (i.e. Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) or Narcotics Anonymous(NA))
     
Q: What are your personal warning signs of relapse?
NOTE: Briefly explore member's personal warning signs.
 
Take some time every day to stop and "check your warning signs." Be on the lookout for signs that you may be heading towards a relapse. Your friends and family can also help you watch for these signs too. It's better to catch yourself early, before your triggers become too severe.
 
Act immediately if you are starting to relapse. 
  • Let your healthcare provider know right away; you may need to change or re-start your medicine or get another counseling appointment
  • Attend an extra meeting of AA or another support group or call your sponsor to discuss how you are feeling.
  • Remember that you can call the Nurse Advice Line if you need help with your symptoms <provide number>.
  • Take good care of yourself. Get out and do things every day, even if you feel like doing nothing. Spend time with family and friends who support you. Talk to them about your feelings.
     
Q: What are your thoughts about this?
[DM Nurse: Assist member in developing a relapse plan.]
Some people who are dealing with addiction may feel very hopeless at times. If you have thoughts of suicide or of hurting yourself or others, let us or your provider know, or call 911 or the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline.
Q: Would you like their phone number to have - just in case you need it?
Yes: it is 800-273-TALK (800-273-8255), TTY: 800-799-4889
NOTE: If member is suicidal or homicidal, follow the appropriate policy for crisis intervention
For women: Women who suffer from addictions are more likely to be victims of abuse. If someone is hurting you, let us or your provider know, or call the National Domestic Violence Hotline.
Q: Would you like to have their number - just in case you need it?
Yes: it is 800-799-SAFE (800-799-7233), TTY: 800-787-3224, or go to their web site at: www.thehotline.org
NOTE: If member is in an abusive situation, follow the appropriate policy for crisis intervention

EducationComponent.Title: Understanding Treatment Options for Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What can you tell me about treatment for substance use disorder?
NOTE: Praise member for correct responses
 
Addiction is a physical disease just like diabetes or high blood pressure. It is considered a brain disease because alcohol and drugs change the brain and how it works.
  • There is no "cure" for addiction, but with good support from your provider, family, and friends, this disease can be managed successfully over your lifetime
  • People who are addicted can lead healthy, happy lives
 
Few people are able to immediately stop their drinking or drug use.
  • Most need help to change their behaviors and life choices
     
It is up to you to make the choice to stop. Others may be there to help, but at the end of the day the choice to change is yours.
 
There are many treatment choices for addiction. You and your provider should talk about the choices and find the path that will be best for you. Taking part in the program that best fits you will help you to stay motivated toward your goal of recovering.
 
Some of the treatments for alcohol and drug addiction include:
  • Inpatient hospitalization or "in-patient detox"
  • Outpatient clinics, office-based treatment, and outpatient detox programs
  • Alcohol or drug use treatment programs such as intensive outpatient or partial hospitalization programs
  • Peer support programs ( e.g., Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), Narcotics Anonymous (NA))
  • Counseling - for the individual and/or the family
     
It may take any one or a combination of more than one treatment program to make the plan that is just right for you. Most programs include supporting abstinence (quitting), and relapse prevention and rehabilitation (changes to your lifestyle). Including your family and friends in your treatment plan is also important.
 
Treatment can help to improve your family, work, and social relationships. Treatment may include medicines. It is important to remember that the goal of medicine treatment is not to replace one drug with another, but to help you on your way to full recovery. If you take any of these medicines, your provider may order a blood test to check your liver.
 
Alcohol: 
  • Naltrexone blocks the physical dependence to opioids and also decrease alcohol use
  • Acamprosate may work by affecting neurotransmitters in the brain to help you maintain abstinence from alcohol
  • Disulfiram causes very painful side effects when even small amounts of alcohol are consumed
  • These medicines are part of a treatment program that includes counseling and family therapies
  • Take these medicines just like your provider told you to, and do not stop them without talking with your provider first
  • Your provider will tell you about the side effects of your medicine, and when to call about them
     
Opioids: 
  • Medicines are the best choice for opioid addiction, when combined with counseling and other support programs
  • Methadone may work by tricking the brain into thinking that the person is still taking opioids
  • Buprenorphine may work by tricking the brain into thinking that the person is still taking opioids
  • Naltrexone blocks the physical dependence to opioids
  • Take all medicine as directed. Talk to your healthcare provider before making any changes to your treatment
  • Your healthcare provider will tell you about the side effects of your medicine, and when to call about them
     
Cocaine 
  • Studies show that people who use cocaine are less likely to overcome their addiction with the help of medicine, and there is no medicine proven to stop addiction to cocaine
  • Treatment is usually an intensive outpatient program
 
Whatever treatment plan is chosen by you and your healthcare provider, it will be up to you to do it. Ask for help as often as you need it.
Q: What questions do you have about this?
NOTE: Answer questions. If member talks about problems or difficulties with their condition, describe how you and member can identify problems and plan next steps.

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Benefits: Coping Skills- Understanding Coping Skills

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What do you see as the benefits of using coping skills?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses e.g. "That`s exactly right!"
 
Q: May I share with you why others have found that working hard to use coping skills is worth it?
NOTE: If permission given:
They have found that using coping skills may:
  • Help you gain control over stress related to living with <condition>
  • Decrease physical symptoms, such as pain and fatigue
  • Allow you to sleep better
  • Help you learn how your thoughts and behaviors affect your mood and outlook on life
  • Give you more confidence that you will be able to handle your health problems
  • Help improve your quality of life
  • If depression:
    • Improve your depression symptoms
    • Help you benefit from depression treatment
    • Help prevent relapse, once your depression has improved
Q: How does this fit in with your own health goals?

Many people with long-term health problems like <condition> struggle with emotions, such as feeling stressed, discouraged, or angry. In trying to feel better, some people may do things that are not healthy, such as staying away from other people, or drinking too much alcohol. Those things are not helpful and may cause harm.
 
Coping skills are healthy ways to deal with stress and emotions.
If behavioral health or chronic pain condition: Using coping skills is a key part of self-managing <behavioral health or chronic pain condition>.
 
Healthy things you can do to help you cope include:
  • Get regular physical activity
  • Use positive self-talk. Tell yourself: Yes, I can! My glass is half full, not half empty!
  • Do things to relax and reduce tension e.g., mental imaging, progressive muscle relaxation, or deep breathing
  • Schedule pleasant activities into your life. Do things that you have enjoyed in the past.
  • Spend time with friends and family who are supportive
  • Share your thoughts and feelings with others
  • Make tasks smaller. Break tasks down into small steps that are easier to deal with.
 
You may not feel like doing much of anything - but taking action to cope with stress and improve your mood can help you feel better.
Q: What questions do you have about this?

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Benefits: Problem-Solving Skills

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Problem-solving skills include knowing how to solve problems as well as being able to:
  • Manage anger and conflict
  • Recognize and change distorted thinking
  • Ask for help
 
If psychotherapy is prescribed: Talk therapy is a good way to get help with solving problems
Q: Are you working on these skills with your therapist?
 
Q: What do you see as the benefits of using problem-solving skills?
NOTE: Praise the member for appropriate responses e.g. "That's exactly right!"
 
Q: May I share with you why others have found that using problem-solving skills is worth it:
NOTE: If permission given
They have found that these using these skills:
  • Keeps them from worrying about what to do
  • Keeps stress and anxiety from taking over
  • Keeps small problems from becoming big problems
  • Helps them feel more confident and hopeful
 
Q: Are you willing to take steps to start using problem-solving skills?
Yes:
NOTE: Assist member in planning next steps. If member is in psychotherapy, refer them back to their therapist for counseling on problem-solving skills.
No:
NOTE: Explore using Motivational Interviewing

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Discuss with Provider: Self-Management

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Taking care of yourself everyday is key to keeping yourself as healthy as possible. The day-to-day care of your <condition> is up to you.
 
If you are not sure about what things you should be doing at home to take care of yourself, it's important to ask your healthcare provider about this soon.
 
Q: Would you like some ideas on questions you can ask your healthcare provider regarding how to take care of your <condition> at home?
NOTE: If permission given:
You can ask:
  • What are the most important things I should do to take care of myself?
  • What do I monitor or test at home? How often? What do I do with the results?
  • Are there lifestyle changes, like diet or exercise that would improve my health?
  • Is there anything I need to avoid or shouldn`t do?
  • I`m afraid of (or worried about) <issue>; what should I do?
 
Q: Would you be willing to talk to your healthcare provider about ways in which you can take care of yourself at home?
Yes:
NOTE: Assist member in planning next steps
No:
NOTE: Explore using Motivational Interviewing

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- How to Self-Manage Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponent.Title: How to Self-Manage Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Self-management means doing all that you can to stop using alcohol or drugsand take better care of yourself.
 
Q: What are you doing to stop using alcohol/drugs and take better care of yourself?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate self-management behaviors
Q: May I give you some tips that other have found helpful ?
NOTE: If permission given:
It helps to:
  • Work as a partner with your healhcare provider. This includes going to all appointments and counseling sessions
  • Follow the prescribed treatment plan including taking medicine and/or attending talk therapy/counseling
  • Tell your healthcare provider if you have any problems following your treatment plan
  • Pay attention to mood changes and anxiety level and report changes to your healthcare provider or counselor. Let them know how your treatment plan is working
  • Get enough rest. Tell your healthcare provider if you are sleeping too much or too little, having night sweats, nightmares or other problems sleeping
 
Q: What areas would you be interested in working on?

Intervention.Desc: If pregnant or could become pregnant, discuss

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Understanding Pregnancy and Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponent.Title: Understanding Pregnancy and Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Tell me what you know about drinking alcohol or using drugs during pregnancy.
Note: Listen and praise the member for what they know
 
Q: Would you like to hear more about the dangers of alcohol, tobacco, and drugs during pregnancy?
Note: With permission
 
The use of drugs and/or alcohol during pregnancy is a harmful mix for mothers and their unborn children. Using alcohol, tobacco, or drugs during pregnancy can harm not only the baby, but also the mother. Women who use alcohol or tobacco or use drugs are at high risk for serious problems in pregnancy. Drinking, smoking, and using drugs are major causes of physical and mental health problems in newborn babies.
 
There are no safe levels of alcohol or drugs during pregnancy.
 
Getting treatment for alcohol/drug use while pregnant carries risks. Some medications used for treatment may cause birth defects. If you are thinking about getting pregnant, get treatment before you do.
 
Risks to the pregnant woman include: 
  • Higher risk of HIV/AIDS, because drinking and drug use increase the likelihood of unprotected sex
  • High risk for developing hepatitis, anemia, tuberculosis, and high blood pressure (preeclampsia/toxemia)
  • Spontaneous abortions (miscarriages) or a long-drawn-out "hard labor"
  • Greater risk of child abuse, neglect and other parenting problems
     
Risks to the baby include: 
  • Substances such as nicotine, opioids, cocaine, and alcohol are known to pass from the mother to the unborn child. That means the unborn baby is vulnerable to whatever the mother is using
  • Alcohol use after the first trimester increases the risk for your child to have Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS).
  • The baby is at greater risk for premature (early) birth, and low birth weight
  • If the mother has HIV/AIDS, there is a high risk that the infection will be passed to the child
  • Many babies of mothers who use or drink during pregnancy are born with addiction problems and have to go through withdrawal from the substance
  • Babies may be born with a life-long condition called fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). Children with FAS can have a small head and brain, heart defects, kidney and bone problems, vision and hearing problems, and physical deformities. They can also have learning disorders, delayed cognitive development, hyperactivity, poor balance and coordination and other problems
  • After birth, alcohol and drugs can be passed to the infant through breast milk while breast feeding
 
Pregnant women who drink or use drugs need to understand the risks and ask for help to quit drinking alcohol or using drugs. If you are pregnant or thinking about becoming pregnant, speak honestly with your healthcare provider about your your substance use disorder. Work closely with your healthcare provider, counselor, and support group during your pregnancy.
 
There are many resources to help pregnant women. There are classes on pregnancy and parenting available in your community. Ask your provider for more information.
 
Q: What questions do you have about this?
Note: Listen empathetically and provide resources for the mother.
 
For women: Women who suffer from addictions are more likely to be victims of abuse. If someone is hurting you, let us or your healthcare provider know, or call the National Domestic Violence Hotline.
Q: Would you like to have their number - just in case you need it?
Yes: it is 800-799-SAFE (800-799-7233), TTY: 800-787-3224, or go to their web site at: www.thehotline.org
NOTE: If member is in an abusive situation, follow the appropriate policy for crisis intervention

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Resources: Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: May I tell you about some resources to get help that others have found useful?
 
NOTE: If permission given, provide as much detail as needed to support memberThese sites have many useful articles and suggestions however we are not affiliated with these organizations and cannot guarantee that the content or the links within them are current or accurate.
  • National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA): Has online information as well as brochures you can order and ebooks you can download.
    • Web: www.drugabuse.gov Select "Publications" to look for the different types of information available
  • National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA): Has online information and brochures available to order.
    • Web: www.niaaa.nih.gov Select "Publications& Multimedia" then " Brochures and Fact Sheets"
  • Alcoholics Anonymous:
    • Web: www.aa.org

Goal.Desc: Has received counseling on alcohol/substance abuse symptom recognition

Problem.Desc: Needs counseling on alcohol/substance abuse symptom recognition

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Discuss with Provider: Symptom Recognition

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Taking care of yourself includes knowing what symptoms to watch for and when to get help. This can help keep little problems from turning into big problems. It can help you stay out of the emergency room or hospital.
 
If you are not sure what to watch for and what to do, it's important to ask your provider about this soon.
Q: Would you like some ideas on questions you can ask your provider regarding symptoms to watch for?
NOTE: If permission given:
You can ask:
  • What symptoms are most important for me to watch for?
  • What am I to do if they occur?
  • What do I do if the symptoms occur during the night, on a weekend, or holiday?
  • For what types of symptoms should I call 911 or go to the emergency room?
  • I`m afraid of (or worried about) <symptom>; what should I do?
 
Q: Would you be willing to talk to your provider about symptoms to watch for and what to do about them?
Yes:
NOTE: Assist member in planning next steps
No:
NOTE: Explore using Motivational Interviewing

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- How to Recognize and Respond to Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder Symptoms

EducationComponent.Title: How to Recognize and Respond to Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder Symptoms

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
People who abuse alcohol or drugs and try to stop can experience withdrawal. Withdrawal from alcohol and certain drugs can be life-threatening. Learn the signs and symptoms of withdrawal, and when to contact your provider or call 911.
 
Q: What can you tell me about symptoms of withdrawal from alcohol or drugs?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses
 
For alcohol: 
  • Feeling of jumpiness or nervousness
  • Feelings of shakiness
  • Anxiety
  • Irritation or getting excited easily
  • Quickly becoming angry or sad
  • Depression
  • Feeling of tiredness
  • Being unable to think clearly
  • Bad dreams
  • Hallucinations
     
 For drugs (including marijuana): 
  • Yawning and other sleep problems
  • Sweating more than normal
  • Anxiety or being nervous
  • Muscle aches and pains
  • Stomach pain, nausea, vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Weakness
  • Depression
 NOTE: Instruct member to discuss any questions regarding action plan instructions with their provider: how to access emergency medical services; and the nurse advice line
 
Q: Do you feel that you know what to watch for and what to do when you have symptoms?
NOTE: If not very confident, explore and problem-solve

Intervention.Desc: If member has action plan, review

Instruction.Desc: Assess knowledge of action plan instructions
Deliver education component(s):- How to Use an Action Plan

EducationComponent.Title: How to Use an Action Plan

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: This is intended as an interactive review of member`s current action plan. Ideally, member would be looking at their action plan while discussing it.
 
Q: May I give you some tips on how to use your action plan?
NOTE: If permission given, discuss the following:
 
Availability
Your action plan is an important tool to help you take care of your <condition>. But, like any tool, if you don`t know where it is or how to use it, it isn`t very useful.
Your action plan should be kept in a place where you can easily and quickly get to it when needed.
Q: Where do you keep your action plan? Are you able to quickly get it when needed?
 
If child 
Q: Does the school or caregiver have a copy of the action plan?
NOTE: As needed, assist member in planning next steps to make action plan accessible
 
Understanding
Q: Tell me about your action plan. What does it tell you to watch out for? What does it tell you to do?
NOTE: As needed, assist member in planning next steps to clarify action plan instructions with provider. Consider using practice scenarios such as "If <symptom> happened, what would you do?"
 
Medications
Some people have action plans that tell them to take different medicines when they start to feel sick.
Q: What does your action plan tell you about your medicines?
If PRN medicines are part of action plan 
Q: Do you have a fresh supply of the medicine that you take only when you are sick? Where do you keep this medicine?
NOTE: As needed, assist member in planning next steps to obtain necessary medications. Instruct member on expiration date and storage precautions.
 
Confidence
Q: Have you ever used your action plan? If yes, tell me what happened.
Q: If needed in future, do you feel that you can follow the instructions on your action plan? NOTE: If not very confident, explore and problem-solve.

Goal.Desc: Has received behavior change counseling on alcohol/substance use disorder

Problem.Desc: Needs behavior change counseling on alcohol/substance use disorder

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Barrier: Believes Alcohol/Drug Use Is Not Serious- Barrier: Believes Cannot Quit Due to Long Alcohol/Drug Use- Barrier: Believes It Is Too Late to Improve Health: Substance Use- Barrier: Has Problems Avoiding Triggers for Substance Use- Barrier: Has Tried to Quit Before and Relapsed: Substance Use- Barrier: Is a Young Person: Substance Use- Barrier: Other- Barrier: Uses Alcohol/Drugs to Relax- Identify Barriers: Cessation of Alcohol/Drugs

EducationComponent.Title: Barrier: Believes Alcohol/Drug Use Is Not Serious

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: Explore and reflect member's feelings
 
You may think that your use of alcohol or drugs is not serious. You may believe that the amount you drink or use is nothing to worry about and will not affect your health, or that you can stop drinking or using at any time. This is called denial. Unhealthy alcohol and drug use can be dangerous to your physical and mental health. It can also lead to addiction and even death. Underage or excess drinking can also cause serious health conditions and even death.
 
Q: May I share with you what research studies have found?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
Studies have shown that using alcohol and drugscan lead to:
 
An increase in the risk of death or injury from:
  • Accidental overdose
  • Car accidents
  • Falls
  • Suicide or other violence
 
An increased risk for health problems, including:
  • Liver, kidney, heart disease, stroke, and high blood pressure
  • Depression and other mental health issues (including memory loss, hallucinations, and confusion)
  • HIV/AIDS from unprotected sex or IV drug use
Methamphetamine users have significant dental problems, including:
  • Losing teeth
  • Cavities
  • Gum disease
If pregnant: 
  • An increase in serious health problems for the mother and developing baby, such as premature delivery
  • Increased risk for the baby to have physical and mental health problems when a pregnant woman consumes alcohol or drugs (e.g., fetal alcohol syndrome, baby addicted to drugs)
  • Increased risk for Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) when using alcohol or tobacco after the first trimester
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

EducationComponent.Title: Barrier: Believes Cannot Quit Due to Long Alcohol/Drug Use

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: Explore and reflect member's barrier
It can be hard to think about change when have used alcohol or drugs for many years
Q: May I share with you what research studies have found about people who have used alcohol or drugs for a long time?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
Studies have found that:
  • Many people who use alcohol/drugs can quit
  • Medicine is available that can increase your chances of quitting successfully. You are more likely to quit if you use medicine and a counseling program together
  • Even if you have used alcohol or drugs for a long time, quitting now can improve the quality of your life and increase the chances that you will live longer
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

EducationComponent.Title: Barrier: Believes It Is Too Late to Improve Health: Substance Use

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: Explore and reflect member's barrier
I understand that you feel you've used alcohol/drugs too long to think your health can get better.
 
Q: May I share with you some ways your health may improve if you quit?
NOTE: If permission given:
Studies have shown many health benefits of quitting, and some of them start right away, such as:
  • A decrease in the risk of death or injury from:
    • Accidental overdose
    • Car accidents
    • Suicide or other violence
    • Falls
  • A decrease in the risk of health problems such as:
    • Liver or heart disease, stroke, high blood pressure
    • Depression
    • HIV/AIDS from unprotected sex or IV drug use
  • A decreased risk of health problems for the mother during pregnancy and the birth, and
    • A lower risk of mental and physical problems for the baby
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

EducationComponent.Title: Barrier: Has Problems Avoiding Triggers for Substance Use

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
There are many things that may help lead you to use drugs or drink alcohol, or make it difficult to stop. We call these events, places and even people "triggers."
 
Q: May I tell you about some of the most common triggers?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
Common triggers include:
  • Cravings or urges to use
  • A desire to feel numb or to cope, especially when life is difficult
  • Fear of withdrawal from alcohol/drugs
  • Easy access to alcohol/drugs
  • Parties, picnics, weddings, family gatherings
  • Marriage, birth of a child, anniversaries (both happy and sad), or new job celebrations
  • Death of family or friend, divorce, job loss
  • Time when there "isn`t anything to do", or feelings of boredom
  • Feeling overwhelmed with trying to follow a quit plan
  • Being around other people who drink or use
     
Q: What questions do you have about this?
Q: What triggers sound like problems that you have?
NOTE: Explore and reflect member`s triggers

EducationComponent.Title: Barrier: Has Tried to Quit Before and Relapsed: Substance Use

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: Explore and reflect member's barrier
It must be discouraging to have tried to quit before and started using alcohol/drugs again. Staying substance free can be difficult sometimes.
Q: May I share with you what others have found?
NOTE: If permission given:
They have found that:
  • Most people try to quit at least 2 or 3 times, and maybe even more, before they quit for good.
  • Each time you try to quit, you are more likely to succeed than the time before.
  • You can learn how to make a better quit plan by thinking about your past attempts. Ask yourself what worked and what didn't.
  • You can ask your healthcare provider for help. They can help you find a counselor and may recommend medicine to help you quit.
  • Your mind is very powerful. It helps to tell you, "I can quit," and "I can take control of my health." In your mind, start to picture yourself as a person who doesn't use drugs or alcohol.
  • Some people find that support groups have helped them to quit successfully (i.e. Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) or Narcotics Anonymous(NA)).
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

EducationComponent.Title: Barrier: Is a Young Person: Substance Use

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: Explore and reflect member's barrier
 
Alcohol and drug use are appealing to some young people, and that can make it hard to stop. Some young people feel that using alcohol or drugs makes them appear more mature or helps them fit in with their friends. If the people you hang out with use drugs and alcohol, it may seem like everyone is doing it, so it must not be a big deal. Sometimes young people use drugs and alcohol to help them cope with something bad that happened to them in the past or because their parents use drugs or alcohol.
Q: Would you like to hear more about substance use among young people?
NOTE: If permission given:
  • The harm that comes from alcohol and drug use is much greater than any good feelings it gives you
  • Use of alcohol and drugs has been associated with an increase in car accidents, criminal acts, difficulty in school (e.g., poor performance, being expelled), engaging in risky behavior like unprotected sex, physical dating violence, and an increased risk of dying from suicide, homicide, or an accident
  • Even if you think you can quit anytime, you might not always be able to quit. Almost everyone who continues to use alcohol/drugs can become addicted. The earlier you stop using alcohol/drugs, the easier it will be to have the willpower to quit
  • TV, internet, social media and radio ads market their products (wine, beer, hard liquor) to make them appealing to young people. Friends you know may tell you that "getting high" is cool. They want to influence your decision about drinking or using, but you can be an independent thinker. You can make a different and better choice for yourself
  • You may have friends who take prescription medicines that are not theirs. They may think this is safe because the medicines were prescribed by a healthcare provider. They may even offer these medicines to you. This type of drug use is not any safer than using "street" drugs. Many of these medicines can be addictive and have side-effects that can cause serious health problems and even death
  • More American teens do not use alcohol/drugsthan those who do. Most do not think it is cool
  • It helps to spend time with people who can encourage you to quit using alcohol or drugs. You don`t need to do it alone. Find someone you trust and ask them for help quitting
  • Real friends shouldn`t reject you for saying "no"
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

Q: What makes it hard for you to <desired behavior change>?
NOTE: Explore, clarify, empathize, and reflect. Summarize a non-judgmental understanding of member's barrier.

Q: What are your thoughts on how to solve this problem?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses and assist with problem-solving PRN

NOTE: Explore and reflect member's barrier
It can be hard to give up something that you think helps you relax.
 
Q: May I share information about using alcohol or drugs to relax?
NOTE: If permission given: 
  • Alcohol and drugs change your brain chemistry and how your brain works every time you use them. These changes may temporarily make you feel less stressed, relaxed and even happy
  • Alcohol and drugs are addictive. If you "need" a drink or a fix and don't have one, you will start to have withdrawal symptoms. Using alcohol and drugscan make you feel less stressed because it decreases the withdrawal symptoms for a while. But these feelings will return unless you have another drink or a fix. You may think it will help you relax, but they actually increase anxiety as a result of withdrawal symptoms, legal trouble, or problems at school, work and in relationships
  • Instead of using alcohol or drugs, find other ways to relax. Healthy ways to relax include deep breathing, meditating, exercise (e.g. short walk, stretching), prayer, listening to music, doing a hobby, or closing your eyes and thinking about a pleasant scene. You can also find fun things to do with people who don`t drink or use drug
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

Q: Some people believe things about alcohol/drugs use that keep them from quitting for good. Do you have any of the following beliefs?
  • Alcohol/drug use is not serious (It won't hurt me if I do use, since everyone else does it)
  • I cannot quit due to long alcohol/drug use (I've used alcohol/drugs for so many years that I probably won't be able to quit.)
  • It is too late to improve my health (It doesn't matter if I stop using alcohol/drugs, because the damage has already been done)
  • I have tried to quit before and relapsed (I can't quit, because I've tried to quit before and then started using alcohol/drugs again)
  • I have problems avoiding substance use triggers ("Everywhere I go there are alcohol and drugs")
  • I need alcohol/drugs to relax or feel numb (I need alcohol to relax.)
  • Alcohol/drug use makes me feel and fit in better (under age 21)
  • Other
 NOTE: If barrier identified, go to corresponding barrier component

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- How to Quit Using Alcohol/Drugs- Keeping a Diary: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Making a Plan: Alcohol/Drug Cessation

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
There are different treatment options to help you successfully quit using drugs/alcohol. Sometimes combining approaches will be more helpful than using one alone. They include:
  • Medicine to help you stop using alcohol/drugs
  • A counseling program (e.g., brief intervention, support groups, cognitive behavioral therapies, technology-based interventions)
  • Peer support groups like Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) or Narcotics Anonymous (NA)
 
Q: What are other thoughts on ways to quit using drugs/alcohol?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses
 
Q: May I give you information about stopping use of drugs/alcohol?
 
NOTE: If permission given, provide as much detail as needed to support member
Withdrawal symptoms can include:
  • Feeling irritable, nervous, frustrated or depressed
  • Having trouble thinking clearly
  • Having trouble sleeping
  • Feeling hungry, even after eating
Use your medicines as directed to help with feelings of withdrawal. Withdrawal is your body letting you know that it's adjusting to being free of alcohol or drugs. As time passes, quitting your substance use will get easier. You will start feeling better and enjoying non-drug activities and rewards
Managing cravings:
  • Wait for the craving for alcohol/drugs to pass
  • Relax by taking slow deep breaths and picturing a pleasant scene
  • Stay away from things, places and people that tempt you to use alcohol/drugs
  • Do things and go places where you are not able to use alcohol/drugs
  • Change daily activities that you associate with using alcohol/drugs
  • Substitute use of alcohol/drugs with healthier options. If you always drink or use when you wake up in the morning, peel and eat a piece of fruit instead. If you drink or use after a meal, go for a walk instead
  • Reward yourself for quitting. Do a pleasant or fun activity or hobby
  • Keep a list of the benefits of being drug/alcohol-free and read it often
  • Remember your goal is to never drink alcohol or use drugs again
 
Q: Which of these tips do you think would work for you?

If still using alcohol/drugs:
You might use alcohl/drugs without even thinking about it. Keeping a diary can help you learn when and why you use them, and when using it is most important to you. When you are ready to quit, review the information in your diary with your healthcare provider or counselor to help make a plan. This may help stay away from anything that makes you want to use alcohol/drugs.
 
Q: May I explain how to keep a diary?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
For the next few weeks, keep track of every time you use alcohol or drugs. Each time you use a alcohol/drugs, write down:
  • The time of day
  • What you were doing
  • Who you were with
  • Where you were
  • How you were feeling (For example, bored, frustrated, tired, happy, etc.)
  • How strongly you wanted to use alchohl/drugs, using a scale of
    • 0 = not at all
    • 1 = just a little
    • 2 = some
    • 3 = a lot
Q: Are you willing to start keeping a diary of your alchohol/drug habit?
If recently quit:
Keeping track of days without alcohol/drugs can show you how well you are doing. A diary can also be a place to make notes about the times it is hard to resist using. You can then plan to avoid these situations.
Q: Are you willing to keep a diary to help you quit using alcohol/drugs?

NOTE: Support change talk e.g. "I'm really glad to hear that you decided to get ready to quit using alcohol/drugs!"
 
Q: What steps might you take to quit?
NOTE: optional A good place to start is to think about other changes you have made.
 
Q: Can you tell me about another change you have been able to make in the past?
 
Q: How were you able to be successful with that change?
NOTE: Summarize member's successful actions
 
Q: What might you do to use these ideas when you are quitting alcohol/drugs?
 
Q: Would you like to hear what has helped others to quit using alcohol/drugs?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
You may want to write down these 3 steps:
 
 
1. GET READY! Quitting alcohol/drugs is a big change. It helps to prepare. You can:
  • Set a quit date
  • If does not have cessation medicine: First, call or make an appointment to see your healthcare provider for help with quitting. Your provider may prescribe medicine and/or refer you to a counseling program
  • If has cessation medicine: Setting a quit date within the next 2 weeks is best. Follow your healthcare provider's instructions about when to start the medicine
  • Prepare for withdrawal symptoms or other challenges
  • Think about ways to avoid things that tempt you to use alcohol/drugs (triggers)
  • Know that you may have feelings of withdrawal and urges to use alcohol/drugs
  • Plan new activities and routines to keep your mind off using slcohol/drugs
  • Plan to reward yourself for quitting
  • Get rid of things that remind you of alcohol/drug use
  • Before your quit date, try to stop using alcohol/drugs in places where you spend a lot of time (e.g. home, with friends)
  • Make your home alcohol or drug-free
  • Throw away all alcohol/drugs, mixers, supplies, equipment or anything related to using alcohol/drugs
2. GET HELP! Counseling and support from other people can help you quit for good. You can:
  • Join a 12 step program like Alcoholics/Narcotics Anonymous(AA /NA). There are many of these groups in your community
  • Ask your provider to connect you with a counseling center or inpatient program to help you quit
  • Call your health insurance company for a list of available treatment facilities in your area
  • Call a quit line such as the SAMHSA National Helpline at 1-800-662-HELP (4357)
  • Tell family, friends and co-workers that you plan to quit
  • If someone close to you uses alcohol/drugs, ask them to quit with you, or at least not use alcohol/drugs around you
  • Ask your healthcare provider: "How can you help me quit using drugs/alcohol? Is medicine for quitting drugs/alcohol the right choice for me?"
 
3. GET MEDICINE! Medicine can increase your chances of quitting for good
  • Ask your healthcare provider what (if any) medicine might be right for you
 
NOTE: Assist member PRN in making good plan based on SMART goals (Specific, Measurable, Actionable, Realistic, Time-bound) and using information from component: How to Quit Using Drugs/alcohol
 
Q: Do you feel you will be able to follow through with the steps we talked about?
NOTE: If not very confident, assist in adjusting plan so member feels confident
 
Q: Are you ready to set a quit date? OR What steps will you take this week to get ready to quit?
NOTE: If member not ready to set a date or start their plan, explore and problem-solve

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Determine Motivational State

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What are your thoughts about taking steps to <desired behavior change>?
  • Decided to change behavior, ready to make a plan
    • NOTE: Go to intervention: Assist to make a plan
  • Has started desired behavior
    • NOTE: Go to intervention: Support new behavior
  • Other
    • NOTE: Go to intervention: Explore behavior change

Instruction.Desc: Proceed to intervention specific to motivational state
Deliver education component(s):- The Problem of Alcohol/Substance Use

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Sometimes, people start drinking too much, take medicines that are prescribed to other people, or turn to street/illegal drugs to manage stress or cope with a chronic condition. Often, people combine alcohol and drugs, or take more than one type of harmful drug. These substances are dangerous and can seriously harm your brain and body, as well as relationships, education and employment. They can:
  • Worsen depression or other health conditions
  • Damage your organs, including your heart, liver, kidneys, and brain
  • Cause you to hurt yourself. For example, they may cause a fall or accident
  • Make you need the substance (physical dependence). This causes uncomfortable symptoms and could lead you to overdose to make the discomfort go away
  • Lead to having a substance use disorder. This happens when all you can think about is getting and using that substance. This can cause you to ruin your relationships with other people and make it even harder to cope
  • Lead to life-threatening situations, including suicide, violence, motor vehicle accidents, accidental overdose, or death
     
If you see yourself using substances to numb emotions or to cope with a chronic condition, it's important that you get help. Talk to your provider or a counselor or join a support group.
 
For teens and children 
  • You can say no to alcohol and drugs. You have the right to make good choices for yourself and say what you do or don't want to do
  • You can say something like, "No, I've decided not to do that"
    • If diabetes: You can say "No thanks, that stuff messes with my diabetes"
  • You can feel good about making the best decisions for yourself
     
For adult with diabetes
Using alcohol or drugs can cause a lot of problems if you have diabetes. Some things you should know about alcohol, drugs, and diabetes:
  • Alcohol can make your blood sugar go too low
  • You may not notice the low sugar feeling because of the alcohol
  • Continuing to drink when your sugar is low can cause you to pass out and then your sugar could go even lower
    • Friends who do not know you have diabetes may think you are just acting different because of the alcohol and may not know that you are in danger
  • On the other hand, wine coolers, beer, and alcohol mixed into sweet fruity drinks will raise your blood sugar
    • If you don`t count carbs and check your sugar, you could end up with a very high blood sugar
  • The dangers of drugs for people with diabetes are like the dangers of alcohol. Using drugs can:
    • Raise or lower your blood sugar
    • Affect your appetite so you either neglect to eat, or eat way too much
    • Cause you to lose interest in taking care of your diabetes
    • Cause you to not take your medicines
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

Instruction.Desc: Advise to discuss alcohol/substance use concerns with provider

Deliver education component(s):- Identify Barriers: Cessation of Alcohol/Drugs- Keeping a Diary: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Respond to Ambivalence: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Respond to Change Talk: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Respond to Relapse/Behavior Drift: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Respond to Resistance: Alcohol/Drug Cessation

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: Some people believe things about alcohol/drugs use that keep them from quitting for good. Do you have any of the following beliefs?
  • Alcohol/drug use is not serious (It won't hurt me if I do use, since everyone else does it)
  • I cannot quit due to long alcohol/drug use (I've used alcohol/drugs for so many years that I probably won't be able to quit.)
  • It is too late to improve my health (It doesn't matter if I stop using alcohol/drugs, because the damage has already been done)
  • I have tried to quit before and relapsed (I can't quit, because I've tried to quit before and then started using alcohol/drugs again)
  • I have problems avoiding substance use triggers ("Everywhere I go there are alcohol and drugs")
  • I need alcohol/drugs to relax or feel numb (I need alcohol to relax.)
  • Alcohol/drug use makes me feel and fit in better (under age 21)
  • Other
 NOTE: If barrier identified, go to corresponding barrier component

If still using alcohol/drugs:
You might use alcohl/drugs without even thinking about it. Keeping a diary can help you learn when and why you use them, and when using it is most important to you. When you are ready to quit, review the information in your diary with your healthcare provider or counselor to help make a plan. This may help stay away from anything that makes you want to use alcohol/drugs.
 
Q: May I explain how to keep a diary?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
For the next few weeks, keep track of every time you use alcohol or drugs. Each time you use a alcohol/drugs, write down:
  • The time of day
  • What you were doing
  • Who you were with
  • Where you were
  • How you were feeling (For example, bored, frustrated, tired, happy, etc.)
  • How strongly you wanted to use alchohl/drugs, using a scale of
    • 0 = not at all
    • 1 = just a little
    • 2 = some
    • 3 = a lot
Q: Are you willing to start keeping a diary of your alchohol/drug habit?
If recently quit:
Keeping track of days without alcohol/drugs can show you how well you are doing. A diary can also be a place to make notes about the times it is hard to resist using. You can then plan to avoid these situations.
Q: Are you willing to keep a diary to help you quit using alcohol/drugs?

NOTE: Explore, clarify, and reflect on member's reasons to change and reasons not to change.
Emphasis is on choice and not forcing solutions
 
To get member to reinforce pros of quitting:
  • Q: On a scale of 1 to 7, how important is it to you to quit using alcohol/drugs? One (1) means that quitting is not important and 7 means it is very important.
  • Q: Why a <member's importance number> and not a <one number lower>? Or What is getting you up to a <member's importance number>?
    • NOTE: Explore to identify several reasons e.g. "What else?"
  • What about the other direction: what would it take to get you up to a <one or two numbers higher>?
    • NOTE: If member has difficulty with the number scale, use the following questions instead.
  • Q: How important is it to you to quit using alcohol/drugs? For example, is it not at all, somewhat, or very important to you?
  • Q: Why <somewhat or very important> instead of <one answer lower>?
    • NOTE: Explore to identify several reasons e.g. "What else?"
  • Q: What would it take for it to be <somewhat or very important> instead of <member's answer>?
 
To create dissonance:
Q: What's important to you in your life (e.g. family, remaining healthy so can be independent etc)?
 
Q: How does alcohol/drug use fit in with <things that are important to member>?
NOTE: Create dissonance e.g. "On one hand you told me you want to be active with your grandchildren as they grow up but on the other hand you continue to use alcohol/drugs"
To check for resistance:
 
Q: What would have to change for you to consider quitting?
NOTE: Reflect, go to component: Respond to Resistance PRN, build self-efficacy e.g. "I believe that you can quit"

EducationComponent.Title: Respond to Change Talk: Alcohol/Drug Cessation

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What have your thoughts been regarding quitting?
NOTE: Reflect, summarize and explore e.g. "Tell me more about that"
 
I really believe that you can quit.
 
Q: Are you ready to start talking about the steps you will take to quit?
 
Yes Wonderful!
NOTE: Go to intervention: Assist to make a plan
 
No Q: What would have to change for you to consider quitting?
NOTE: Reflect, discuss possible barriers. Use components that will be helpful.

EducationComponent.Title: Respond to Relapse/Behavior Drift: Alcohol/Drug Cessation

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
It must be very frustrating to quit using alcohol/drugs, but then start using again (relapse).
 
Q: May I share information about relapses with you?
 
NOTE: If permission given: 
  • Most people need several tries before they quit for good. Each try is a way to learn more about what it will take to quit.
  • It is important NOT to think of this as a failure. Instead, think of it as practice for quitting the next time.
  • You can feel good about the time you went without using alcohol/drugs. Because you quit for awhile, you are one step closer to quitting for good.
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?
It is important to understand what triggered you to start using alcohol/drugs again.
 
Q: What happened that led you to relapse?
NOTE: Reflect, empathize
 
Q: What do you think you can do next time to avoid this trigger, or to keep from using alcohol/drugsif it happens again?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses and assist with problem-solving PRN
 
Q: May I share with you some other ways to deal with a relapse?
NOTE: If permission given:
When you quit alcohol/drugs again, it is important to remember that the goal is to not use drugs/alcohol at all. If you relapse and start using:
  • Don`t say "It's a lost cause" or let yourself use drugs/alcohol the rest of the day or week
  • Get rid of any remaining alcohol/drugs
  • Make that your last use and quit again at once
  • Remind yourself that it is a setback, but not a failure
  • Think about how you can stay away from or deal with the situation that caused you to relapse
 
Q: Are you ready to try quitting again?
Yes Wonderful!
NOTE: go to intervention: Assist to make a plan
 
No Q: What would have to change for you to consider trying again?
NOTE: Reflect, go to components: Respond to Ambivalence and build self-efficacy e.g. "I believe that you can quit"
Q: What are your thoughts about this?
It is important to understand what triggered you to start using drugs/alcohol again.
Q: What happened that led you to relapse?
NOTE: Reflect, empathize
 
Q: What do you think you can do next time to stay away from this trigger, or to keep from using alcohol/drugsif the trigger happens?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses and assist with problem-solving PRN

If unwilling:
NOTE: Explore, clarify, empathize, and reflect. Summarize a non-judgmental understanding of member's position. Avoid argumentation or persuasion
 
Q: What would have to happen for you to consider quitting?
 
If discouraged because of failed quit attempts:
Alcohol/drug use is an addiction and it is tough to get clean and sober.
 
Q: May I share with you what others have found?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
They have found that::
  • Most people need several attempts at quitting before they are finally clean and sober. Each attempt is a way to learn more about yourself and what it will take to quit. If you quit for a short time, and then start using drugs/alcohol again, you are still one step closer to quitting for good
  • Think of it like riding a bicycle; you must fall off a few times before you succeed. Falling off doesn't mean you will never learn to ride the bicycle or that you are a failure
  • You can ask your provider for help with quitting alcohol/drugs. Medicines are now available that can increase your chances of being successful in quitting. You are even more likely to be able to quit if you use medicine and a counseling program together
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?
 
Q: Can you tell me what part of your quit plan worked in the past?
Q: What got in the way?
NOTE: Reflect, empathize. Assist with problem-solving PRN.
 
If nothing will convince member to quit:
I hear you saying you are not ready to quit using alcohol/drug right now. I'm here to help you when you are ready.
NOTE: Do not discuss further in this contact, unless member indicates they want to continue.

Instruction.Desc: Deliver education component(s):- Resources: Alcohol/Substance Use Disorder

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: May I tell you about some resources to get help that others have found useful?
 
NOTE: If permission given, provide as much detail as needed to support memberThese sites have many useful articles and suggestions however we are not affiliated with these organizations and cannot guarantee that the content or the links within them are current or accurate.
  • National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA): Has online information as well as brochures you can order and ebooks you can download.
    • Web: www.drugabuse.gov Select "Publications" to look for the different types of information available
  • National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA): Has online information and brochures available to order.
    • Web: www.niaaa.nih.gov Select "Publications& Multimedia" then " Brochures and Fact Sheets"
  • Alcoholics Anonymous:
    • Web: www.aa.org

Intervention.Desc: Review benefits for behavioral health coverage

Instruction.Desc: Refer to health plan resources
Deliver education component(s):- Continues Behavior: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Recently Started: Alcohol/Drug Cessation- Respond to Relapse/Behavior Drift: Alcohol/Drug Cessation

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: Provide emotional support by praising member "You're doing a great job!"
Tell me what you do to avoid using alcohol/drugs
 
Q: Is there anything that could get in the way of staying free of alcohol or drugs?
 
Yes Q: What are your thoughts on how to prevent them from getting in the way?
NOTE: Assist with problem-solving PRN
 
Q: May I tell you ways to continue your great progress?
NOTE: If permission given:
  • Know and be aware of possible triggers. Even a long time after quitting use of alcohol/drugs, certain places and events can make a person feel like starting again
  • Reward yourself for not using alcohol/drugs. Remind yourself why being free of these thingsis good for your life
  • Ask for support from others to help you stay free of alcohol/drugs
  • Consider joining a support group (i.e. Alcoholics Anonymous (AA), Narcotics Anonymous (NA), or Marijuana Anonymous (MA))
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

NOTE: Provide emotional support by praising member "You're doing a great job!"
Tell me how you are able to avoid using alcohol/drugs
 
Q: Do you feel that you can continue to not use drugs/alcohol?
 
Q: Is there anything that might get in the way of staying free of alcohol/drugs?
Yes Q: What are your thoughts on how to manage barriers to remaining alcohol/drug-free?
NOTE: Assist with problem-solving PRN
 
Q: May I tell you about ways to overcome the challenges that you might face?
NOTE: If permission given:
Others have learned that it is important to:
  • Keep trying to quit. Even a long time after you stop using alcohol/drugs, certain places and events can make you feel like using again
  • Keep rewarding yourself for not using alcohol/drugs. Remind yourself often of the good things about being alcohol/drug free
 
Q: What are your thoughts about this?

Instruction.Desc: If strategy has NOT been initiated, proceed to other interventions
Recommended-- Member has two scheduled visits or phone calls with provider during the first month of alcohol/substance abuse cessation
